text:
South Dakota tourism officials upbeat after successful summer Published on : Friday, September 11, 2015
Travel and tourism officials of South Dakota gathered in Rapid City recently to work on marketing strategies and review the main travel season.
An upbeat bunch of members of the Governor’s Tourism Advisory Board has reason to celebrate what is likely to be one of the best summer seasons ever.
“Everything just set up so nicely for this summer,” said state Tourism Secretary Jim Hagen. “Gas prices, in some instances, a dollar or more cheaper than they were a year ago at this time. What we really saw was a lot of pent-up demand, from visitors who hadn’t been taking vacations for a number of years because of the economy saying ‘this year we’re going.'”
The 75th Sturgis Motorcycle Rally helped, too. While the rally does hurt certain tourism business catering to families – many of whom tend to stay away during the early August rally – it brought up overall numbers and spending. Hundreds of thousands of bikers will have that effect.
Hagen expects a strong autumn season, highlighted by the 50th Custer State Park Buffalo Roundup later this month.
After a soggy spring in some areas, excellent summer weather overall had people hitting the road. At the long-popular Reptile Gardens, good news came early and kept coming.
“We had an absolutely fabulous summer,” said Reptile Gardens public relations manager John Brockelsby. “Every month we were open — April, May, June, July, August — up, up, up, up. So we couldn’t be more pleased with the visitor numbers we had this year.”
Revenues from the tax are up 17 percent from this time a year ago, which was up 2 percent to 3 percent from the year before. Hagen said the 17 percent hike in the tax revenue reflected a much greater impact from the spending overall.
Tourism is the second largest industry in South Dakota, with visitors spending more than $865 million statewide.
